qas.question: What power was Congress given by the Constitution?

answers.text: borrow money on the credit of the United States

qas.question: What did Congress authorize the Federal Reserve Banks to do?
What are the notes issued by the Federal Reserve?
Where, other than any Federal Reserve bank, can notes be redeemed?
Since the 1970s, what is the only type of note that has remained in circulation?

plausible_answers.text: borrow money on the credit of the United States

qas.question: What power was Congress given by the Federal Reserve?
What did the Constitution authorize the Federal Reserve Banks to do?
What are the noted issued by Congress?
Where, other than Congress can notes be redeemed?
Since the 1970s, what is the only type of note that have been designated?

context: The U.S. Constitution provides that Congress shall have the power to "<a0_0><b5_0>borrow money on the credit of the United States<b5_0/><a0_0/>". Congress has exercised that power by authorizing Federal Reserve Banks to <a1_0><b6_0>issue Federal Reserve Notes<b6_0/><a1_0/>. Those notes are "<a2_0><b7_0>obligations of the United States<b7_0/><a2_0/>" and "shall be redeemed in lawful money on demand at the Treasury Department of the United States, in the city of <a3_0><b8_0>Washington, District of Columbia<b8_0/><a3_0/>, or at any Federal Reserve bank". Federal Reserve Notes are designated by law as "legal tender" for the payment of debts. Congress has also authorized the issuance of more than 10 other types of banknotes, including the United States Note and the Federal Reserve Bank Note. The <a4_0><b9_0>Federal Reserve Note<b9_0/><a4_0/> is the only type that remains in circulation since the 1970s.
